name: Orrest Head
desc: A short climb rewarded with Wainwright's first Lake District view — the panorama that started it all.
terrain: Woodland and open fell

directions.instruction: From Windermere town centre, cross the A591 main road. You'll see a brown sign for 'Orrest Head' pointing up a narrow lane.
Follow the lane uphill for 100m, then go through the kissing gate on your left into the woodland. The path is clear and well-trodden.
Climb steadily through mixed woodland. The path zigzags — follow the main trail, ignoring smaller side paths.
After about 15 minutes, you'll emerge from the trees onto open fell. The summit is the obvious high point ahead.

Reach the Orrest Head viewpoint (238m). This is where Wainwright first saw the Lakes aged 23 — there's a memorial plaque. Take in the panorama: Windermere stretches out below, with the Langdale Pikes and Coniston Old Man beyond.
Continue north along the ridge for extended views, then loop back via the path heading east.
Descend through pasture and back into woodland. Follow signs back to the kissing gate and retrace your steps to town.

parkingDetail: Broad Street Car Park, Broad St, Windermere LA23 2AB (pay and display, free after 6pm). Grid Ref: SD 414 987. Alternatively, Windermere Station Car Park, Station Rd, Windermere LA23 1AH (pay and display).
thePayoff: A short climb rewarded with Wainwright's first Lake District view — the panorama that started it all.

name: Tarn Hows
desc: A picture-perfect lake loop through one of the most photographed spots in England — gentle, stunning, and unforgettable.
terrain: Gravel paths

directions.instruction: From the Tarn Hows Car Park, exit the car park and follow the clear, wide path downhill towards Tarn Hows itself.
Upon reaching the tarn, you'll arrive at a clear junction. Turn left here to begin the anti-clockwise circuit of Tarn Hows.
Follow the well-maintained, gravel path as it gently undulates along the western and northern shores, offering continuous views across the water.
Continue along the eastern shore, passing several benches and viewpoints. The path remains clear and easy to follow.
The path will eventually lead you past the outflow of the tarn (Tom Gill Beck) and then gently ascend as you complete the southern section of the loop.
As you complete the full circuit, the path will curve back towards the initial junction near the car park entrance.
Rejoin the main path and follow it directly back uphill to the Tarn Hows Car Park where you started.

parkingDetail: National Trust Tarn Hows Car Park, LA21 8DP. Pay and display: £6.50 for up to 2 hours, £8 for over 2 hours (card payment only). Free for National Trust members. Can be very busy, especially at peak times – arrive early or late.
thePayoff: A picture-perfect lake loop through one of the most photographed spots in England — gentle, stunning, and unforgettable.

name: Aira Force
desc: A magical gorge walk to a 20-metre waterfall plunging through a stone bridge — Wordsworth wrote about this place.
terrain: Stone steps and wooded gorge

directions.instruction: From the car park, follow the main path downhill, signposted for Aira Force.
At the junction, bear left to descend towards the lower bridge and the main waterfall viewing area.
Cross the lower bridge over Aira Beck. After crossing, turn left and follow the path upstream on the right bank of the beck, enjoying views of the gorge.
Continue ascending via stone steps and well-maintained paths, passing several viewpoints, until you reach the main 20-metre Aira Force waterfall.
Proceed further upstream, past the main waterfall, and cross the upper bridge.
After crossing the upper bridge, turn left and follow the path downstream on the left bank of Aira Beck, heading back towards the car park.
Continue on the path, passing the lower bridge area, and ascend back to the car park.

parkingDetail: National Trust Aira Force Car Park, A592, CA11 0JS. Parking is free for National Trust members. Non-members pay £7 for up to 2 hours, £10 for up to 4 hours, and £12 for all day. Well-signed from A592.
thePayoff: A magical gorge walk to a 20-metre waterfall plunging through a stone bridge — Wordsworth wrote about this place.

name: Catbells
desc: The most popular family summit in the Lakes — a thrilling ridge walk with Derwentwater sparkling below.
terrain: Steep rocky path and ridge

directions.instruction: From the Gutherscale roadside parking (lay-by), cross the road carefully and locate the clear footpath signposted for Catbells, heading steeply uphill through woodland.
Follow the well-trodden path as it climbs relentlessly, soon emerging from the trees onto the open fellside. The path becomes rocky and steep in places.
Continue upwards, navigating any minor scrambles. You will reach a prominent false summit (Skelgill Bank). The true summit of Catbells is visible ahead.
Descend slightly from the false summit, then ascend again along the narrow, exhilarating ridge to reach the trig point at the summit of Catbells (451m). Enjoy the panoramic views.
From the summit, continue south along the undulating ridge, descending towards the col known as Ha'penny Gate, which lies before the steeper ascent to Maiden Moor.
At Ha'penny Gate, turn right (west) onto the clear bridleway that descends gently, traversing the western flank of Catbells. This path offers excellent views over Newlands Valley.
Follow this lower path as it gradually descends, passing through gates and eventually leading back towards the B5209 road near Hawes End.
Upon reaching the road, turn right and walk carefully along the roadside (or use any available verge/path) for approximately 0.5 km back to the Gutherscale lay-by where you started.

parkingDetail: Hawes End National Trust car park (CA12 5UE, Grid Ref: NY 246 201). Free for NT members, pay & display for non-members. Spaces are limited and fill quickly, especially on weekends and holidays. Alternative: Very limited free roadside parking (lay-by) near Gutherscale (approx. NY 244 208) at the given coordinates. Consider arriving by Keswick Launch boat at Hawes End landing for a car-free option.
thePayoff: The most popular family summit in the Lakes — a thrilling ridge walk with Derwentwater sparkling below.

name: Helvellyn via Striding Edge
desc: England's most famous mountain ridge — a genuine scramble with 600m drops either side, ending at the third-highest peak in the Lakes.
terrain: High mountain ridge and scramble

directions.instruction: From Glenridding car park, follow signs for 'Helvellyn via Striding Edge'.
Climb steadily onto Birkhouse Moor. The path is clear and well-trodden.
Reach the 'Hole-in-the-Wall' — a gap in the stone wall. Go through it.
The Striding Edge ridge begins. You have a choice: traverse the very crest for the full scramble or use the path below to the right.
Follow the ridge, using hands where needed. The exposure is significant, offering thrilling views.
After the final rocky tower, scramble up to the summit plateau of Helvellyn.
Descend via Swirral Edge (northeast). This is steep and rocky, requiring care.
Pass below Catstye Cam and follow the path down past Red Tarn.
Follow Red Tarn Beck (which becomes Mires Beck) north back to Glenridding. Celebrate with a well-deserved refreshment!

parkingDetail: Glenridding main car park, CA11 0PD. Pay & display. Fills early in summer — arrive before 8am on weekends.
thePayoff: England's most famous mountain ridge — a genuine scramble with 600m drops either side, ending at the third-highest peak in the Lakes.

name: Loughrigg Fell
desc: Loughrigg Fell offers one of the Lake District's most rewarding short walks. From its accessible summit, walkers are treated to a stunning 360-degree panorama encompassing Windermere, Rydal Water, and Grasmere, making it a favourite for all abilities.
terrain: Rocky fell and stone paths

directions.instruction: Exit White Moss Car Park, turn left (north) on the A591 for a short distance, then cross the road carefully to the footpath on the opposite side.
Turn left onto the path signposted 'Loughrigg Terrace' or 'Grasmere'. Follow this path through woodland, with Rydal Water on your left.
Continue along Loughrigg Terrace, enjoying views over Grasmere. Look for a clear, pitched path ascending steeply to your left (south) towards Loughrigg Fell summit.
Climb the pitched path, which becomes less steep higher up, navigating rocky outcrops to reach the true summit of Loughrigg Fell.
From the summit, descend south-eastwards on a clear path, heading towards Rydal Water. The path will lead you past Rydal Cave (optional detour).
Continue on the main path from Rydal Cave, which eventually leads back towards the A591.
Cross the A591 carefully at the designated crossing point and return to White Moss Car Park.

parkingDetail: White Moss Car Park, A591, near Grasmere, LA22 9SE. National Trust pay and display. Two car parks at White Moss — the main one is clearly signed from the A591.
thePayoff: A stunning 360-degree panorama of Windermere, Rydal Water, and Grasmere from a relatively accessible summit.

name: Gummer's How
desc: This short, rewarding walk offers the best 'effort-to-view' ratio in the Lake District. Ascend through woodland to the summit of Gummer's How for breathtaking panoramic views across the entire length of Windermere and the surrounding fells.
terrain: Woodland path and stone steps

directions.instruction: From Gummer's How Car Park, locate the main path heading uphill from the northern end, marked by a wooden signpost.
Follow this clear, well-maintained path as it ascends steadily through the coniferous woodland, passing through a gate.
Continue on the path, which becomes rockier and features some stone steps, winding its way upwards.
As you emerge from the trees onto more open, heathery ground, follow the worn path and cairns directly to the trig point at the summit of Gummer's How.
From the summit trig point, turn to face south-east (away from Windermere) and follow a less distinct path that descends gently over rocky ground, aiming towards the eastern side of the hill.
This path will lead you down through scattered trees, eventually rejoining the main ascent track further down the hill.
Turn left onto the main track and follow it downhill, retracing your steps back to Gummer's How Car Park.

parkingDetail: Gummer's How Car Park, FELL FOOT BROW, LA12 8NP. A large, free Forestry England car park. Grid Ref: SD 392 879. No fees or National Trust membership required.
thePayoff: The best 'effort-to-view' ratio in the Lake District, offering a bird's-eye view of the entire length of Windermere.

name: School Knott
desc: A peaceful escape from the village crowds with a perfect reflection of the fells in the hidden School Knott Tarn.
terrain: Grassy slopes and fields

directions.instruction: From Windermere Railway Station, walk down Victoria Street (the main road) towards the village centre.
Turn left onto Ellerthwaite Square, then immediately right onto Ellerthwaite Road.
Continue along Ellerthwaite Road, passing Ellerthwaite Lodge, until you see a public footpath sign on your left leading uphill through fields.
Follow this well-defined public footpath, crossing stiles and ascending gradually, with views opening up behind you.
Continue on the path as it leads directly to the grassy summit of School Knott, marked by a small cairn.
From the summit, head slightly east (a short descent) to discover the hidden School Knott Tarn.
Walk around the tarn, then pick up the path heading generally north-east, then north, through fields and tracks, passing through gates and stiles.
This path will eventually lead you back to the outskirts of Windermere village. Follow the roads back to Windermere Railway Station.

parkingDetail: Windermere Railway Station Car Park, WINDERMERE, LA23 1AH. Operated by Westmorland and Furness Council. Pay and display, fees apply (check current rates on site). Grid Ref: SD 414 986.
thePayoff: A peaceful escape from the village crowds with a perfect reflection of the fells in the hidden School Knott Tarn.

name: Brant Fell
desc: This easy circular walk from Bowness-on-Windermere quickly ascends to Brant Fell, offering stunning panoramic views of Windermere and its islands. The route follows a mix of quiet roads and well-maintained grassy paths, making it a perfect short outing for families or those seeking a rewarding vista without a strenuous climb.
terrain: Steep road and grassy paths

directions.instruction: Exit Braithwaite Fold Car Park, turn right onto the A592 (Windermere Road).
At the mini-roundabout, turn left onto Longland Road, heading uphill.
Continue up Longland Road, passing the Hydro Hotel on your left.
Look for a public footpath sign on your right, leading up a track. Take this path.
Follow the clear path uphill, passing through gates, until you reach the summit of Brant Fell.
From the summit, continue on the path heading generally south-west, then south, descending gradually.
The path will eventually join Helm Road. Follow this road downhill back towards Bowness and the car park.

parkingDetail: Braithwaite Fold Car Park, BOWNESS-ON-WINDERMERE, LA23 3HB. Large pay and display car park near the lake shore. OS Grid Ref: SD 402 969.
thePayoff: An incredible 'postcard' view over the islands of Windermere and the bustling Bowness bay.

name: Todd Crag
desc: A rewarding short walk offering a spectacular vista straight down the barrel of Lake Windermere from a high rocky perch. This popular route from Ambleside takes you past the charming Lily Tarn before a final scramble to the summit of Todd Crag.
terrain: Walled lane and rocky fell

directions.instruction: From Miller Bridge Car Park, cross Miller Bridge over the River Rothay directly into Rothay Park.
Follow the main path through Rothay Park, keeping the river on your left. Exit the park near the cricket pitch onto Under Loughrigg road.
Turn right onto Under Loughrigg road, then almost immediately take the first left onto a narrow, walled lane (often signed 'Footpath to Loughrigg').
directions.landmark: Under Loughrigg Road, Footpath to Loughrigg

directions.instruction: Follow this steep, stone-walled lane as it climbs steadily. It eventually opens out onto the fellside. Continue uphill, passing the picturesque Lily Tarn on your left.

From Lily Tarn, continue on the main path heading generally west. Todd Crag is the prominent rocky outcrop to your right, slightly off the main path to Loughrigg Fell summit. Scramble up to the highest point for the best views.

Descend from Todd Crag back to the main path. Instead of returning past Lily Tarn, take the clear path that bears left (south-east) and descends more directly towards Ambleside, offering views over Windermere.
Follow this path as it winds down, eventually joining a track that leads back to Under Loughrigg road.
Turn left onto Under Loughrigg road and retrace your steps through Rothay Park and over Miller Bridge back to the car park.

parkingDetail: Miller Bridge Car Park, Ambleside, LA22 0EE. A small, popular pay and display car park operated by Westmorland and Furness Council. No National Trust benefits apply. Grid Ref: SD 373 035.
thePayoff: A spectacular vista straight down the barrel of Lake Windermere from a high rocky perch.

name: Wansfell Pike
desc: A true mountain experience with a dramatic ridge walk and a charming finish in the valley of Troutbeck.
terrain: Stone steps, ridge, and stony track

directions.instruction: From King Street Car Park, head east through Ambleside town centre. Turn left onto Stock Ghyll Lane and follow the road uphill, signposted for Stock Ghyll Force.
Continue past the entrance to Stock Ghyll Force waterfall. The main track continues uphill. At the clear fork, take the right-hand path which is signposted for Wansfell Pike.
directions.landmark: Stock Ghyll Force, Wansfell Pike signpost

directions.instruction: Ascend steadily on the clear, often stony path. You will pass through several gates and over stiles. The path becomes steeper as you approach the summit ridge.
Reach the prominent cairn and trig point at the summit of Wansfell Pike (482m). Take time to enjoy the panoramic views across Windermere and the surrounding fells.
directions.landmark: Wansfell Pike Summit, Cairn, Trig Point

directions.instruction: From the summit, descend east-northeast along the clear path. You will pass through a wall via a gate or stile, joining the well-defined track known as Nanny Lane. Follow Nanny Lane downhill towards the village of Troutbeck.
At the bottom of Nanny Lane, you will emerge onto a minor road in Troutbeck. Turn right and walk south along this road for a short distance.
Look for a public footpath on your right, often signposted for Ambleside or Skelghyll Wood. Take this path, which leads through fields and then into the beautiful Skelghyll Wood.

Follow the well-marked woodland path through Skelghyll Wood. The path eventually descends back towards the southern end of Ambleside, emerging near the A591. Turn right to return to the town centre and King Street Car Park.
directions.landmark: Skelghyll Wood, A591, Ambleside town centre

parkingDetail: King Street Car Park, AMBLESIDE, LA22 9AN. This is a large, central pay-and-display car park operated by Westmorland and Furness Council. Fees apply daily. Grid Reference: NY 375 045. Be aware of short-stay limits in some sections. National Trust membership is not applicable here.
thePayoff: A true mountain experience with a dramatic ridge walk and a charming finish in the valley of Troutbeck.

name: Helm Crag
desc: This classic out-and-back walk from Grasmere village leads you directly to the distinctive summit of Helm Crag. The highlight is getting up close to the iconic 'Lion and the Lamb' rock formation, offering superb panoramic views across the surrounding fells and a unique perspective down into the hidden Easedale valley.
terrain: Fields, clear fell path, steep sections, and a rocky ridge

directions.instruction: From Broadgate Meadow Car Park, exit and turn right (south) onto the main road (A591) towards Grasmere village.
Walk through Grasmere village, passing shops and cafes. Continue until you reach the junction with Easedale Road on your right, just before the Grasmere Sports Field.
Turn right onto Easedale Road.
After approximately 200-300 meters, look for a signed public footpath on your left, marked 'Helm Crag' or 'The How'. This is a clear bridleway.
Take this path, which immediately begins to ascend the fells, passing through a gate and then alongside a wall.
Follow the well-defined path as it climbs steadily, initially through fields and then onto open fellside, offering increasingly expansive views.
The path leads directly to the rocky ridge of Helm Crag. Scramble carefully to the true summit (the 'Lion and the Lamb' formation) for the best views.
directions.landmark: Helm Crag summit, 'Lion and the Lamb'

directions.instruction: After enjoying the views, descend by carefully retracing your steps along the same path back to Broadgate Meadow Car Park.

parkingDetail: Broadgate Meadow Car Park, GRASMERE, LA22 9TA. This is a large, well-maintained pay-and-display car park located on the northern edge of the village, near the play area. It is not a National Trust car park. Grid Ref: NY 338 076.
thePayoff: Getting up close to the iconic 'Lion and the Lamb' rock formation and peering down into the hidden Easedale valley.

name: Latterbarrow
desc: The massive stone obelisk at the summit feels like a secret monument with views of the entire Fairfield Horseshoe.
terrain: Village lanes, grassy slopes, and forest paths

directions.instruction: Exit Hawkshead Main Car Park and turn right, then immediately left to walk north through the village. Pass the shops, pubs, and St Michael and All Angels Church on your right.
directions.landmark: Hawkshead village, St Michael and All Angels Church

directions.instruction: At the junction beyond the church, turn left onto the B5285 (signposted for Sawrey/Windermere). Walk carefully along the road for about 150m.
Just before the road bends sharply right, turn right onto a narrower lane, Loanthwaite Lane (signposted for Colthouse). Follow this lane, passing houses and a small chapel.
Continue on Loanthwaite Lane for approximately 1 km. Look for a public footpath sign on your left, leading through a gate and uphill towards Latterbarrow. Take this path.

Follow the clear path as it ascends steadily across open fields and grassy slopes. The prominent stone obelisk at the summit of Latterbarrow will become visible ahead. Continue climbing directly towards it.

Reach the summit of Latterbarrow (244m) and the large stone obelisk. Enjoy the panoramic 360-degree views. From the obelisk, descend northwards on a clear path, leading into the woods of Sawrey Ground.

Follow the path through the woods, which eventually emerges onto a track. Turn left onto this track, which leads back towards Colthouse and then Hawkshead. Retrace your steps through the village to the car park.

parkingDetail: Hawkshead Main Car Park, HAWKSHEAD, LA22 0NT. Large pay and display car park (Westmorland and Furness Council). Machines accept cards and cash. National Trust membership does not provide free parking here. Grid Reference: SD 352 879.
thePayoff: The massive stone obelisk at the summit feels like a secret monument with views of the entire Fairfield Horseshoe.

name: Silver How
desc: This popular circular walk from Grasmere ascends to the summit of Silver How, offering unparalleled panoramic views of Grasmere Lake and the surrounding fells. The route traverses woodland and rocky fell paths, passing the historic Allan Bank on its way to one of the Lake District's most rewarding viewpoints.
terrain: Woodland and rocky fell paths

directions.instruction: From Grasmere Car Park, turn left onto Red Bank Road. Walk through Grasmere village, passing St Oswald's Church and the Grasmere Gingerbread Shop.
directions.landmark: St Oswald's Church, Grasmere Gingerbread Shop

directions.instruction: Continue along Red Bank Road for a short distance, then turn right onto the lane signposted 'Allan Bank'.
Follow this lane uphill, passing the entrance to Allan Bank (National Trust property) on your left.
Continue on the main track beyond Allan Bank. The track climbs steadily, becoming a rocky fell path.
Follow the clear path as it ascends to the summit of Silver How, enjoying panoramic views of Grasmere Lake and the surrounding fells.
From the summit, descend south-eastwards on a clear path, initially heading towards Chapel Stile.
The path will curve left (north-east) and descend more steeply, eventually joining Red Bank Road.
Turn left onto Red Bank Road and follow it back down into Grasmere village, returning to the car park.

parkingDetail: Grasmere Car Park (Red Bank Road), GRASMERE, LA22 9TA. Pay and display car park. National Trust membership does not apply for this car park.
thePayoff: A front-row seat to the beauty of Grasmere Lake, often cited as the loveliest view in the Lake District.

name: Claife Heights
desc: Two magical tarns — Moss Eccles and Wise Een — sit in open moorland with Coniston Old Man on the horizon, a landscape Beatrix Potter loved and helped preserve for the nation.
start: Braithwaite Hall Car Park, Far Sawrey
terrain: Woodland paths (conifer and deciduous), open heathland sections, and some lakeside paths.

directions.instruction: From Braithwaite Hall car park, exit and turn left (west) onto the minor road. Walk past Braithwaite Hall on your right.
Continue along the lane. After approximately 200m, where the lane bends sharply left, take the signposted public footpath on your right, heading uphill into the woodland.
Follow the clear path as it winds through woodland, generally heading west/southwest. Ignore minor side paths and continue until you reach the beautiful Moss Eccles Tarn.
From Moss Eccles Tarn, continue on the main path (generally southwest) for a short distance to reach the smaller, more open Wise Een Tarn. Enjoy the views towards Coniston Old Man.
From Wise Een Tarn, follow the path that heads generally east/southeast, climbing slightly. You will pass through a section known as Highs Moss, where the path enters denser conifer plantation.
Continue on the clear track through the extensive woodland of Claife Heights. There are occasional viewpoints and clearings. Follow the main track, generally heading northeast.

The path will eventually begin a clear descent, emerging from the woodland into fields. Follow the well-defined path northeast, passing through gates and stiles, which will lead you back towards the village of Far Sawrey and the car park.

parkingDetail:
Primary: Braithwaite Hall, Far Sawrey, LA22 0LL (approx. grid ref: SD 370 954). Small honesty box car park (typically £2-£3 donation). Limited spaces.
Alternatives (both National Trust Pay & Display, free for NT members):
1. Harrowslack Car Park, LA22 0LR (approx. 24 spaces).
2. Ash Landing Car Park, LA22 0LR.
All car parks are accessed via narrow, single-track lanes from Far Sawrey village.
thePayoff: Two magical tarns — Moss Eccles and Wise Een — sit in open moorland with Coniston Old Man on the horizon, a landscape Beatrix Potter loved and helped preserve for the nation.

name: Fairfield Horseshoe
desc: A magnificent high-level ridge walk bagging eight Wainwrights in one sweep, with 360-degree panoramas from Fairfield summit (873m) stretching from the Helvellyn range to the sea.
terrain: High mountain ridges and steep descent

directions.instruction: Start at Rydal Road Car Park, Ambleside. Exit the car park and turn left (north) onto Rydal Road (A591). Walk briefly along the pavement, passing the Ambleside Salutation Hotel.
directions.landmark: Rydal Road Car Park, Ambleside Salutation Hotel

directions.instruction: Just after passing Rydal Mount (on your left), look for a clear public footpath sign on your right, leading steeply uphill. Follow this well-defined path, which climbs steadily through woodland and then open fellside, heading towards the prominent ridge. This path leads directly to the summit of Nab Scar.

From Nab Scar (363m), continue northwards along the clear ridge path. The route undulates over Heron Pike (612m) and then Great Rigg (766m), offering expansive views. Follow the path as it gradually ascends towards the broad summit plateau of Fairfield.
directions.landmark: Nab Scar, Heron Pike, Great Rigg, Fairfield

directions.instruction: Reach the summit of Fairfield (873m), marked by a large cairn. Take time to enjoy the 360-degree panoramas.

From Fairfield's summit, begin your descent eastwards. The path can be indistinct initially but generally follows the ridge down towards Hart Crag (821m). From Hart Crag, continue south-east along the ridge to Dove Crag (792m), passing over a rocky section.

From Dove Crag, continue south-east along the clear path, descending towards High Pike (656m). After High Pike, the path continues to Low Pike (508m), the final Wainwright on the eastern arm of the horseshoe.
directions.landmark: Dove Crag, High Pike, Low Pike

directions.instruction: From Low Pike, follow the path as it descends more steeply southwards, eventually joining a track that leads down towards Scandale Beck. Cross the beck via a footbridge and continue on the track, which eventually becomes a tarmac lane (Scandale Road). Follow Scandale Road back into Ambleside, turning right onto Rydal Road to return to the car park.
directions.landmark: Low Pike, Scandale Beck, Scandale Road, Rydal Road

parkingDetail: Rydal Road Car Park, Ambleside, LA22 9AN. Large pay & display car park off the A591. Pay by phone code 9917. Chargeable 8am–8pm daily. This is the main car park for Ambleside town centre and the standard starting point for the Horseshoe.
thePayoff: A magnificent high-level ridge walk bagging eight Wainwrights in one sweep, with 360-degree panoramas from Fairfield summit (873m) stretching from the Helvellyn range to the sea.

name: Scout Scar
desc: This popular circular walk explores the dramatic limestone escarpment of Scout Scar, offering stunning views across the Lyth Valley and beyond. The route culminates at the unique 'mushroom' shelter, providing an unparalleled vantage point over the southern Lake District and Morecambe Bay. It's an accessible and rewarding experience for all abilities.
terrain: Limestone escarpment and open ridge

directions.instruction: From the Scout Scar car park (the old quarry), take the clear, wide path leading directly uphill towards the escarpment. Follow the path as it gently ascends, passing through a gate or gap in the wall.
At the top of this initial climb, you'll reach a junction with the main ridge path. Turn right (north) and follow this well-defined path along the top of the limestone escarpment.

Continue along the ridge, enjoying expansive views to your left (west) over the Lyth Valley and to the distant Lakeland fells. The distinctive 'mushroom' shelter (Shelter Stone) will soon come into view.

Reach the mushroom shelter, a perfect spot for a break and to soak in the panoramic views, including Morecambe Bay to the south. From here, continue north along the main escarpment path, following the clear track.

After approximately 800m past the mushroom shelter, as the path begins a gentle descent and curves slightly left, look for a clear track branching off to your left (west), descending more steeply down the grassy slope. Take this track.
Follow this descending track. It will lead you down to a lower, wider bridleway that runs parallel to the escarpment. Turn left (south) onto this bridleway.

Continue along this lower bridleway, with the escarpment now on your left. The path will gently undulate and eventually lead you back towards the car park area, passing through a gate or gap in the wall.
As you approach the car park, the bridleway will merge with the initial ascent path, bringing you directly back to your starting point in the quarry.

parkingDetail: Scout Scar Car Park (free), Underbarrow Road, Kendal, LA8 8HB. This is the SECOND car park on the right after leaving Kendal and crossing the A591 — do not stop at the first car park (by the mast). The car park sits in an old quarry. OS Grid Ref: SD 48991 91500. Postcode covers a wide area so ignore satnav if it takes you past — the quarry car park is approximately 1.5 miles out of Kendal on the Underbarrow Road.
thePayoff: Ascend to the iconic 'mushroom' shelter on Scout Scar for breathtaking 360-degree panoramas, sweeping from the distant Lakeland fells to the shimmering expanse of Morecambe Bay.

name: Easedale Tarn
desc: Sourmilk Gill — a magnificent cascade of white water tumbling down a rocky gorge — leads dramatically to a remote, perfectly still tarn cradled between Tarn Crag and Blea Rigg.
terrain: Steep rocky path and tarn shore

directions.instruction: From Broadgate Meadow Car Park, turn left onto the A591, then immediately cross the road carefully and turn right onto Easedale Road, signposted for Easedale.
Follow Easedale Road past the Youth Hostel and several holiday cottages. The tarmac lane soon becomes a clear track.
Go through a gate (often with a 'Welcome to Easedale' sign) and continue on the clear track with Easedale Beck on your left. The path is relatively flat here.
The track begins to climb more steeply, with a wall on your right. The path becomes rockier and ascends alongside Sourmilk Gill, a magnificent cascade of white water.
Continue climbing alongside Sourmilk Gill. As you reach the top of the gill, the landscape suddenly opens up to reveal the serene Easedale Tarn, cradled between Tarn Crag and Blea Rigg.
For the circular return, walk along the northern shore of Easedale Tarn. At the far western end of the tarn, cross the stepping stones over the outflow (Easedale Beck).
Once across the stepping stones, turn right and follow the clear bridleway that heads southeast, gently descending back towards Easedale Road.
Continue on the bridleway until it rejoins the outward track/road near the cottages. Turn left and retrace your steps along Easedale Road back to Broadgate Meadow Car Park.

parkingDetail: Broadgate Meadow Car Park (north of Grasmere village), Grasmere, LA22 9RQ. Grid Ref: NY 338 076. Pay & display (card/cash/app), 81 spaces, open daily. Alternatively, Stock Lane Car Park (south approach), LA22 9SJ. Grasmere village centre car parks fill quickly in summer — arrive before 10am.
thePayoff: Sourmilk Gill — a magnificent cascade of white water tumbling down a rocky gorge — leads dramatically to a remote, perfectly still tarn cradled between Tarn Crag and Blea Rigg.

name: Rydal Water & Caves
desc: Rydal Cave — a vast, cathedral-like abandoned slate quarry with a luminous turquoise pool inside — is one of the Lake District's most dramatic and unexpected hidden gems.
terrain: Woodland path and loose scree

directions.instruction: From White Moss South car park, carefully cross the A591 at the designated crossing point or where safe, then turn left onto the pavement.
directions.landmark: A591, White Moss South Car Park

directions.instruction: Walk a short distance (approx. 50m) along the pavement until you see a clear, signposted path on your right, leading down towards Rydal Water. Take this path.
Follow the well-maintained path along the northern shore of Rydal Water, keeping the water on your right. You will pass through pleasant woodland.

After approximately 1.5-2 km, look for a clear path branching off to your left, ascending gently towards the hillside. This path is usually signposted for 'Loughrigg Cave' or 'Rydal Cave'. Take this path.
Follow the path directly to Rydal Cave (also known as Loughrigg Cave). Take time to explore the impressive quarry and its luminous pool.

From the cave entrance, continue on the main path, which ascends more steeply past the cave. Follow this path as it curves around the hillside, eventually joining the wider, flatter path known as Loughrigg Terrace.
Turn left onto Loughrigg Terrace and enjoy the panoramic views across Grasmere and Rydal Water. Follow Loughrigg Terrace westwards.
As the path begins to descend, it will lead you back towards the A591 and the White Moss car park area. Look for clear paths descending to the road, then cross back to the car park.

parkingDetail: White Moss Car Park (South), A591, near Grasmere, LA22 9SE. Pay & display, National Trust. Two car parks at White Moss: the south car park is the correct one for this route (if coming from Grasmere direction, it's on the right after the north car park on the left). Toilets with baby-changing facilities on site.
thePayoff: Rydal Cave — a vast, cathedral-like abandoned slate quarry with a luminous turquoise pool inside — is one of the Lake District's most dramatic and unexpected hidden gems.

name: Buttermere Shoreline
desc: A perfect lake circuit with dramatic fell reflections, a secret rock tunnel carved through the cliff face, and Haystacks — Wainwright's favourite mountain — watching over every step.
terrain: Flat lakeside paths and rock tunnel

directions.instruction: From Buttermere National Park Car Park, walk south through Buttermere village towards the lake.
Turn left (east) onto the minor road and follow it along the northern shore of the lake towards Gatesgarth.
At Gatesgarth, cross the bridge over Buttermere Dubs and join the footpath that follows the southern shore of the lake.
Continue along the well-maintained path, passing through the Hassness Estate and its famous rock tunnel.
The path continues along the western side of the lake, offering views back towards the village.
Follow the path as it eventually leads back to the northern end of the lake and the village.
Return to the car park.

parkingDetail: Buttermere National Park Car Park (LDNPA), Buttermere, CA13 9UZ. Pay & display. The lake is a short walk south from the village. Arrive early in summer as it fills quickly. The Fish Hotel (CA13 9XA) is nearby for post-walk refreshments.
thePayoff: A perfect lake circuit with dramatic fell reflections, a secret rock tunnel carved through the cliff face, and Haystacks — Wainwright's favourite mountain — watching over every step.

name: Great Langdale Valley
desc: The dramatic Langdale Pikes — Pike O'Stickle, Harrison Stickle, Pavey Ark — dominate the skyline as you stroll the ancient glacial valley floor, where Neolithic axe-makers once worked the same fells.
terrain: Glacial valley floor, stony tracks and fields

directions.instruction: From the Old Dungeon Ghyll car park, turn right (east) and walk along the road past the Old Dungeon Ghyll Hotel. Look for a clear footpath on your left shortly after the hotel.
Take this footpath, which runs parallel to the road, heading east (down valley) towards Sticklebarn. This path offers excellent views of the valley.
Continue on this well-maintained path, passing Wall End Farm. The path will eventually lead you to the New Dungeon Ghyll (Sticklebarn) National Trust car park and cafe.
directions.landmark: New Dungeon Ghyll (Sticklebarn) NT Car Park & Cafe

directions.instruction: At Sticklebarn, cross the main road (B5343) and then cross the Great Langdale Beck via the footbridge (or nearby road bridge) to reach the south side of the valley.
Once on the south side of the valley, turn right (west) and follow the clear footpath that runs along the valley floor, heading back towards the Old Dungeon Ghyll.
This path will take you past Side House and through fields, offering superb views of the Langdale Pikes to your right (north side of the valley).
Continue on this path, which eventually merges with the road, until you reach the vicinity of the Old Dungeon Ghyll Hotel and car park, completing the circular route.

parkingDetail: Old Dungeon Ghyll National Trust Car Park, Great Langdale, LA22 9JU. Pay & display (NT members free). At the very head of the valley, adjacent to the Old Dungeon Ghyll Hotel. Grid reference NY286061. Alternatively, use the New Dungeon Ghyll (Sticklebarn) NT car park, LA22 9JX, 1 mile east. Both are well-signed from the B5343.
thePayoff: The dramatic Langdale Pikes — Pike O'Stickle, Harrison Stickle, Pavey Ark — dominate the skyline as you stroll the ancient glacial valley floor, where Neolithic axe-makers once worked the same fells.

name: Cathedral Cavern - Tilberthwaite
desc: Cathedral Cavern — a 40-foot-high cathedral of volcanic rock hewn by Victorian quarrymen — is entered through a dramatic tunnel and dwarfs all who stand inside, with light filtering through a natural 'window' in the rock above.
terrain: Rough tracks, dark tunnels and quarry spoil heaps

directions.instruction: From Tilberthwaite Car Park, walk west along the main track, passing High Tilberthwaite Farm on your right.
Continue on the clear track, passing through a gate. The track climbs gently, offering views of the valley.
At the next significant junction, take the left fork (often signposted or clearly leading towards Hodge Close/Cathedral Cavern). Follow this path as it descends slightly into the quarry area.
Locate the main entrance to Cathedral Cavern on your left, a dramatic tunnel leading into the cavern. Explore the impressive main chamber and the 'window' above.
Exit Cathedral Cavern and retrace your steps briefly to the main path. Turn left, following the path that heads generally south-east, descending towards Low Hall Garth.
Continue on this path, passing Low Hall Garth Hut on your left. The path soon becomes a wider track.
Follow the track as it leads you back to the main track near High Tilberthwaite Farm. Turn left to return to Tilberthwaite Car Park, completing the circular route.
directions.landmark: High Tilberthwaite Farm, Tilberthwaite Car Park

parkingDetail: Tilberthwaite Car Park, Tilberthwaite, near Coniston, LA21 8DG. Grid reference NY306009. Large layby/car park on the left, accessed via a single-track road signposted 'Tilberthwaite' from the A593 between Ambleside and Coniston. Cashless parking via RingGo app. Limited spaces — arrive early in summer. The road can be icy in winter.
thePayoff: Cathedral Cavern — a 40-foot-high cathedral of volcanic rock hewn by Victorian quarrymen — is entered through a dramatic tunnel and dwarfs all who stand inside, with light filtering through a natural 'window' in the rock above.

name: Skelwith Bridge to Elterwater
desc: This popular circular walk from Elterwater village offers a perfect blend of natural beauty and historical interest. Discover three contrasting waterfalls – the impressive Skelwith Force, the secluded Colwith Force, and the picturesque Slater Bridge – as you follow winding paths through tranquil woodland, open parkland, and the stunning Little Langdale valley.
terrain: Gravel paths, woodland and farmland

directions.instruction: From the Elterwater National Trust car park, head towards the village green. Take the clear footpath signed 'Skelwith Bridge' which runs alongside Great Langdale Beck, keeping the river on your right.
directions.landmark: Elterwater National Trust Car Park, Great Langdale Beck

directions.instruction: Follow the path as it winds past Elter Water on your right. Continue through the open parkland, keeping the river on your right. You'll soon reach Skelwith Bridge.

At Skelwith Bridge, cross the main road (A593) and turn right over the bridge spanning the River Brathay. Immediately after crossing, a short path on your left leads to Skelwith Force waterfall. After viewing, return to the road and continue straight, following signs for 'Colwith Force'.
directions.landmark: Skelwith Bridge, A593, River Brathay, Skelwith Force

directions.instruction: The path continues through fields and woodland, passing Park Farm. Follow the well-trodden track, which can be muddy in places, towards Colwith Force. You'll reach a small hamlet called Stang End.
directions.landmark: Park Farm, Colwith Force, Stang End

directions.instruction: At Stang End, look for a turning on your left, signposted 'Slater Bridge'. Follow this path down to the picturesque packhorse bridge. Take time to admire the bridge and the river below.
Cross Slater Bridge and continue on the track heading generally northeast. This path will lead you through the beautiful Little Langdale valley, passing farmhouses and open fields.

Continue on this track, which eventually becomes a tarmac lane, leading you back into Elterwater village. Follow the lane through the village to return to the National Trust car park where you started.
directions.landmark: Elterwater village, Elterwater National Trust Car Park

parkingDetail: National Trust car park at Elterwater (LA22 9HU). Pay & Display for non-members, free for National Trust members. Grid Ref: NY 328 048.
thePayoff: A delightful circular walk linking the charming village of Elterwater with the powerful Skelwith Force, the hidden Colwith Force, and the iconic Slater Bridge, all connected by scenic paths through the heart of Langdale.

name: Tom Ghyll Waterfalls
desc: A dramatic series of cascading waterfalls leading to the picturesque Tarn Hows, one of the most photographed spots in the Lake District.
terrain: Steep waterfall path and woodland track

directions.instruction: Exit the Glen Mary National Trust car park and follow the clear, signposted path heading uphill towards Tarn Hows.
Follow the well-maintained trail uphill, keeping Tom Gill (the stream) on your right as you ascend through the woodland.
Pass the dramatic series of cascading waterfalls along Tom Gill; take care as the path can be steep and potentially slippery in places.
Continue climbing until you emerge from the trees directly at the southern edge of the picturesque Tarn Hows.
Turn left to follow the accessible, relatively flat circular path around Tarn Hows in a clockwise direction.
Enjoy the panoramic views across the tarn, including the iconic Langdale Pikes visible in the distance, as you complete the circuit.
Continue until you return to the entry point at the head of Tom Gill, where you first emerged from the woods.
Descend back towards the car park, either by retracing the waterfall path or taking the adjacent, slightly less steep woodland track that runs parallel for parts.

parkingDetail: Glen Mary Bridge National Trust car park, LA21 8DP. Pay and display (free for NT members). Located on the A593 between Coniston and Skelwith Bridge.
thePayoff: A dramatic series of cascading waterfalls leading to the picturesque Tarn Hows, one of the most photographed spots in the Lake District.

name: Hodge Close Quarry
desc: The dramatic 'Skull' reflection in the deep blue waters of the massive slate quarry and the incredible Cathedral Cavern.
start: Informal parking area at Hodge Close Quarry
terrain: Woodland path and rocky tracks

directions.instruction: From the informal parking area, walk down the track into Hodge Close Quarry itself. Spend some time exploring the dramatic quarry face and the 'Skull' reflection in the water.

Return to the parking area. With the quarry entrance behind you, turn left (east) onto the track. Follow this track uphill for a short distance, then take the clear footpath on your right, signposted towards Little Langdale and Slater Bridge.
Follow this well-trodden path as it winds through woodland and open areas, often rocky and uneven underfoot. You'll pass through gates and over small streams.
Continue until you reach the picturesque Slater Bridge, a packhorse bridge over the River Brathay. Cross the bridge and turn left, following the path towards Cathedral Cavern.
The path will lead you directly to the entrance of Cathedral Cavern. Explore the impressive main chamber and its various tunnels and openings. (A torch is recommended for deeper exploration).
Exit Cathedral Cavern and retrace your steps slightly. Instead of crossing Slater Bridge again, look for a clear track heading generally north-west, signposted back towards Hodge Close.
Follow this track, which will eventually join a minor road (often very quiet). Continue along this road/track, passing a few cottages.
The track will lead you directly back to the informal parking area at Hodge Close Quarry where you started.

parkingDetail: Very limited, informal free parking directly at Hodge Close Quarry (LA21 8DJ, OS Grid Ref: SD 316 016). This small area fills quickly and is often full. Alternative paid parking is available at Tilberthwaite National Trust Car Park (LA21 8DG, free for NT members) or various informal spots in Little Langdale.
thePayoff: The dramatic 'Skull' reflection in the deep blue waters of the massive slate quarry and the incredible Cathedral Cavern.

name: Blea Tarn Langdale
desc: One of the most iconic views in England, with the Langdale Pikes perfectly reflected in the still waters of the tarn.
terrain: Larch plantation and tarn shore

directions.instruction: From the Blea Tarn National Trust car park, locate the main gate/stile at the northern end of the car park, leading onto a clear track. Pass through and follow the well-defined path, keeping Blea Tarn on your left.
The path gently descends and then levels out, winding through a beautiful larch plantation. Enjoy the iconic views across the tarn to the majestic Langdale Pikes.
Continue along this path, which can be a little uneven with roots and stones in places, until you reach the southern end of Blea Tarn.
At the southern end, you will come to a small wooden footbridge (or a series of small bridges) crossing the stream that flows into/out of the tarn. Cross these bridges.

After crossing the bridge(s), turn left to continue the circular route. The path now runs along the eastern shore of the tarn, with the water on your right. This section is generally flatter and more open.
Follow the clear, well-maintained path as it gently curves northwards, bringing you back towards the starting point.
The path will eventually lead you back to the gate/stile you passed through at the beginning, rejoining the car park.

parkingDetail: Blea Tarn National Trust car park, LA22 9PG (OS Grid Ref: NY 294 043). Pay and display, free for National Trust members. Access is via a narrow, steep mountain road (Fell Foot Brow/Wrynose Pass side), which requires careful driving.
thePayoff: One of the most iconic views in England, with the Langdale Pikes perfectly reflected in the still waters of the tarn.

name: Coniston Old Man
desc: Breathtaking 360-degree views across the Lake District and out to Morecambe Bay, combined with fascinating industrial ruins.
start: Coniston Tourist Information Centre Car Park
terrain: Steep rocky mountain and slate works

directions.instruction: Start from the Coniston Tourist Information Centre Car Park. Exit the car park and turn left onto the main road (A593).
Walk a short distance along the A593, then turn left onto the road signposted 'Walna Scar'. Follow this road uphill, passing houses.
Continue as the road narrows and becomes a rough track, known as Walna Scar Road. Follow this track for approximately 1.5 km.
Look for a clear path branching off to the right, just before a small bridge over Church Beck. This path ascends steeply alongside Church Beck, often referred to as the Boulder Valley path.

Follow this path, ascending steadily through the old slate workings. The path can be rocky and steep in places. Continue past disused mine buildings and spoil heaps, eventually reaching the main ridge path.
Turn left onto the main ridge path and follow it to the summit of Coniston Old Man, marked by a trig point and cairn. Enjoy the panoramic views.
From the summit, descend north-east following the clear path towards Low Water. Pass Low Water on your left, continuing to descend steeply alongside the outflow stream.

The path eventually merges with the main track (Miners Track) that leads back down to Walna Scar Road. Turn right onto Walna Scar Road and retrace your steps back to Coniston village and the car park.

parkingDetail: Coniston Tourist Information Centre Car Park, Coniston, LA21 8HU. Large pay and display car park in the village center. Charges apply daily. This is not a National Trust car park. OS Grid Ref: SD 304 975.
thePayoff: Breathtaking 360-degree views across the Lake District and out to Morecambe Bay, combined with fascinating industrial ruins.

name: Langdale Pikes
desc: A classic Lake District fell walk ascending to the prominent Langdale Pikes. This challenging circular route takes you past the beautiful Stickle Tarn, up to the iconic summits of Harrison Stickle and Pike of Stickle, before descending via the dramatic Dungeon Ghyll.
terrain: Stone paths, rocky waterfalls and high mountain plateau

directions.instruction: Start from the New Dungeon Ghyll car park and follow the clear, well-built stone path heading north, signposted for Stickle Tarn and Stickle Ghyll.
Ascend alongside Stickle Ghyll, climbing the 'giant's staircase' of stone steps, enjoying the waterfalls and cascades.
Arrive at Stickle Tarn. Take the path to the left (west) of the tarn, which begins a steep and rocky climb towards Harrison Stickle.
Reach the summit of Harrison Stickle. Take time to enjoy the panoramic views, especially the dizzying drop into Great Langdale.
From Harrison Stickle, follow the clear path west across the high mountain plateau to the distinctive domed summit of Pike of Stickle.
From Pike of Stickle, descend south-east towards Martcrag Moor, then pick up the clear path heading south, descending steeply alongside Dungeon Ghyll.
Continue the steep and winding descent, passing the impressive Dungeon Ghyll waterfall on your right.
The path eventually leads back to the valley floor, rejoining the initial path that leads directly back to the New Dungeon Ghyll car park.

parkingDetail: Sticklebarn and New Dungeon Ghyll National Trust car park, Great Langdale, Ambleside LA22 9HJ. OS Grid Ref: NY 290 063. Pay and display (free for National Trust members).
thePayoff: The exhilarating feeling of standing atop Harrison Stickle and Pike of Stickle, rewarded with breathtaking, dizzying views straight down into the majestic Great Langdale valley.

name: Staveley Riverside & Woodlands
desc: A charming loop that combines the tranquil River Kent with the ancient, bluebell-filled Craggy Wood and local artisan shops.
terrain: Riverside paths, lanes and ancient woodland

directions.instruction: From Staveley Mill Yard car park, walk towards the main road (A591).
Carefully cross the A591 and turn right, walking north along the pavement (or parallel path) towards the village centre.
After a short distance, turn right onto Kentmere Road, passing the Eagle and Child pub on your left.
directions.landmark: Kentmere Road, Eagle and Child pub

directions.instruction: Continue along Kentmere Road. Just before Barley Bridge, take the signed public footpath on your left that leads down to the River Kent. Follow this path upstream, keeping the river on your right.

Continue along the riverside path, passing through gates and over stiles. You will eventually reach a prominent footbridge. Cross this footbridge to the east bank of the River Kent. Immediately after crossing, turn left and follow the path uphill into Craggy Wood.
Follow the clear path through Craggy Wood, enjoying the ancient trees and, in spring, bluebells. The path gently undulates and eventually descends, emerging onto a quiet lane (Grassgarth Lane).
Turn left onto this lane and follow it downhill. It will lead you back towards Staveley village.
The lane will bring you back to the A591. Carefully cross the A591 again to return to Staveley Mill Yard car park.

parkingDetail: Staveley Mill Yard, LA8 9LR. Free parking is available (please respect business spaces). The closest train station is Staveley.
thePayoff: A charming loop that combines the tranquil River Kent with the ancient, bluebell-filled Craggy Wood and local artisan shops.

name: Troutbeck Tongue
desc: Troutbeck Tongue offers a unique 'valley-center' vantage point, providing fantastic 360-degree views of the surrounding high fells without requiring a massive climb. This moderate circular walk combines charming village lanes and farm tracks with a rewarding ascent up a steep, grassy ridge. It's an excellent choice for those seeking grand Lakeland panoramas with a manageable effort.
terrain: Village lanes, farm tracks and steep grassy ascent

directions.instruction: From the lay-by near Jesus Church, walk north into the historic village of Troutbeck.
At the northern end of the village (Town Head), turn right down the narrow Ing Lane.
Cross Hagg Bridge over the Trout Beck and follow the track towards the fells.
Continue along the track as it passes through the fields of Troutbeck Park Farm.
Look for the path on the left that strikes steeply up the front of the Tongue.
Reach the summit cairn for a grandstand view of the High Street mountain range.
Descend the gentler slopes to the north before picking up the valley floor path.
Follow the riverside path south through the valley to return to Hagg Bridge.

parkingDetail: Parking lay-by on the A592 near Jesus Church, LA23 1PG. Limited spaces; additional parking in Troutbeck village.
thePayoff: A fantastic 'valley-center' vantage point offering unique 360-degree views of the surrounding high fells without a massive climb.

name: South to Winster
desc: A peaceful escape into the undulating 'hidden' Winster Valley, featuring lush rolling hills and ancient dry stone walls.
terrain: Field paths, country lanes and woodland

directions.instruction: Carefully cross the B5284 (Crook Road) from the hotel entrance. Directly opposite, take the public footpath (signposted) that heads generally south-east across fields, keeping the hedge on your left initially.
directions.landmark: Gilpin Hotel & Lake House, B5284, Public Footpath

directions.instruction: Continue on the footpath, passing through or by Gilpin Farm. The path emerges onto a quiet minor road. Turn left onto this lane.
Follow this quiet lane south-east as it winds through the countryside. Continue until you reach the main road through Winster village (B5284). The Brown Horse Inn will be visible on your right.

Walk through Winster village, passing the Brown Horse Inn. Just past the inn, take the minor road/lane that forks off to the right (west), signposted towards Mitchelland or similar. This is a bridleway.
Follow this quiet lane/bridleway as it gently ascends and then descends, heading generally west-north-west. You'll pass a few scattered houses and farms.
Continue on this lane as it passes through the small hamlet of Mitchelland. The lane will then turn more directly north, still a quiet country lane.
Follow this lane north, passing through woodland sections and open fields. It will eventually bring you back to the B5284 (Crook Road).
Turn right onto the B5284. Walk carefully along the road (using any available verge) for a short distance until you reach the entrance to the Gilpin Hotel & Lake House on your left.

parkingDetail: Gilpin Hotel & Lake House, LA23 3NE. Private guest parking only. Public parking is not available at the start point.
thePayoff: A peaceful escape into the undulating 'hidden' Winster Valley, featuring lush rolling hills and ancient dry stone walls.

name: St Catherine's Church
desc: A tranquil discovery of the 'new' St Catherine's Church and the lonely, evocative tower of the medieval old church.
terrain: Road verges, field paths and woodland

directions.instruction: Start from the roadside parking near the Gilpin Hotel on the A5074 (Crook Road). Head east along the A5074, using the wide grass verge where available, for approximately 0.7 km.
Turn left into the driveway for St Catherine's Church (LA23 3NF). Explore the church and its grounds.
Exit St Catherine's Church driveway and turn right, continuing east along the A5074 for another 200m. On your left, you will see the lonely, evocative tower of the medieval Old Crook Church.

Just past the Old Crook Church Tower, look for a signposted public footpath on your left (north side of the road). Take this path, which initially heads north-west, gently ascending through fields towards Lindeth Fell Country House.
directions.landmark: Public footpath, Lindeth Fell Country House

directions.instruction: Continue on the footpath, passing Lindeth Fell, and follow the clear path as it enters a small belt of woodland, then emerges into open fields, heading generally north towards High Lindeth. Enjoy the views across the valley.
From High Lindeth, follow the public footpath that bears south-west, descending through fields and past Lindeth Howe Country House.
directions.landmark: High Lindeth, Lindeth Howe Country House

directions.instruction: Continue on this path as it eventually leads you back down to the A5074 (Crook Road).
Turn right onto the A5074 and walk west for approximately 0.5 km, returning to your starting point near the Gilpin Hotel.

parkingDetail: Limited roadside parking is available on the A5074 (Crook Road) near the Gilpin Hotel (LA23 3AD). Alternatively, for more reliable and official public parking, consider using car parks in Bowness-on-Windermere, such as Rayrigg Road Car Park (LA23 3BZ), which would extend the overall walk distance slightly to reach the Gilpin Hotel.
thePayoff: A tranquil discovery of the 'new' St Catherine's Church and the lonely, evocative tower of the medieval old church.
